titlestmt.titleproper: Program for Art on Film records
Finding Aid for the Program for Art on Film Records, 1951-1999, undated IA20008
titlestmt.author: Sue Luftschein

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-09-26 17:38:35 -0700.

did.unittitle: Program for Art on Film records

did.physloc: To access physical materials at the Getty, go to the library catalog record for this collection and click "Request an Item." Click here for general library access policy. See the Administrative Information section of this finding aid for access restrictions specific to the records described below. Please note, some of the records may be stored off site; advanced notice is required for access to these materials.
did.abstract: Records include correspondence, memoranda, printed matter, minutes, financial and legal documents, films, CD-ROMs, slides, and ephemera produced and collected by the Program for Art on Film, 1951-1999 and undated. Included in the collection are records created and collected by the Program for Art on Film. Among the records created by the Program are correspondence, publications and related correspondence and memoranda, and films. Also included in the records are interviews with filmmakers, in both audio cassette and transcript format, information on two symposia organized by the Program, and records of the Advisory and Managing Committees. Materials collected by the Program include subject files, primarily on art historical topics and film-related topics; information on filmmakers, art historians and artists; brochures and catalogs from film production and distribution companies; information (catalogs, press releases, brochures) on art-related film festivals, both domestic and international; and published materials.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: The Program for Art on Film amassed a large collection of books, videos, magazines, journals, and other printed materials. This material was separated from the collection and transfered to the Getty Research Library for evaluation. All eligible material was incorporated into the library collection and is available to researchers.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: A preliminary inventory was begun in 2004 by Phil Curtis; in 2005 Sue Luftschein completed the bulk of the inventory and encoded this finding aid as a preliminary inventory. No physical processing, beyond reboxing into acid-free record storage boxes, has been undertaken. Any arrangement provided below is purely intellectual.
[Throughout the entire collection are repeated cases of multiple copies of materials that will need to be weeded, particularly publications.]

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: These records originated in accession no. 2004.IA.14. The collection was shipped from the New York Public Library (original box numbers 1-73D) and a storage facility in Long Island City, New York (original box numbers 74-126B). The records arrived in almost no apparent order.

Additional materials was transferred by Nadine Covert in relation to the Art on Screen database. The records were accessioned as accession no. 2008.IA.08. A set of the final version of the Art on Film/Film on Art videos was accessioned as 2011.IA.08. Additional materials were accessioned as 2011.IA.52.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Cite the item and series (as appropriate)], Records, 1951-1999 and undated (bulk 1984-1997), Program for Art on Film. Institutional Archives, Research Library, Getty Research Institute, Finding aid no. IA20008.

phystech.head: Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Films, video and audio tapes require viewing and listening devices.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Contact Rights and Reproductions at the Getty Research Institute for copyright information and permission to publish.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: The records in accessions 2004.IA.14, 2008.IA.08, 2011.IA.08, and 2011.IA.52, subject to review for permanently closed information, are open to qualified researchers. Requests for access will be reviewed on a case-by-case basis.

The following types of records are permanently closed: records containing personal information, records that compromise security or operations, legal communications, legal work product, and records related to donors. The J. Paul Getty Trust reserves the right to restrict access to any records held by the Institutional Archives.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Records consist of correspondence, letters, press releases, clippings, articles, memos, notes, reports, photographs, films, magazines, journals, CD-ROMs, audio cassettes, slides, financial documents, legal documents, curriculum vitae, catalogs, brochures, inventories, books, posters, minutes, surveys, and transcripts created and collected by the Program for Art on Film, 1951-1999 and undated. Included in the collection are records created by the Program for Art on Film (publications and films), and a large collection of records collected by the Program.

The records created by the Program describe the development, production, promotion and distribution of Art on Film projects. The Program for Art on Film produced a number of reference works that are included or mentioned in the records, such as the Art on Film Database, begun in 1984; Art on Screen: A Directory of Films and Videos about the Visual Arts (G.K. Hall & Co., 1992); Art Museums and Media (1994); and The Art on Screen Handbook: Practical Guidelines for Using and Producing Films, Videos and Interactive Programs about Art (1994). The Program's Production Laboratory produced 14 films for its Art on Film/Film on Art series, many of which received awards and all of which are described and included in the records. Among the filmmakers, artists and art historians who collaborated on some of these films are Philip Haas, David Hockney and Ernst Gombrich. The records also describe the day-to-day administrative management of the Program through strategic planning reports and advisory and managing committee meeting minutes, information on the Program's joint ventures with the J. Paul Getty Trust, the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Columbia University and Pratt Institute. The Program's work on symposia, conferences, and educational outreach activities is documented in the records describing Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen, Art on Film, and screenings of its films. The activities of the Production Laboratory are also documented in the records, and can be found throughout all the subseries.

The records also include materials collected by the Program, such as informational materials (in the form of press releases, brochures and catalogs) on national and international companies and organizations that produce and distribute films on art; individual films (both feature and documentary) that take as subject artists or art; and conferences that screen films on art. The "people files" document filmmakers, art historians, and other individuals with interest in film and/or the arts; some of the individuals represented in the records served as evaluators for the Program's publications (including its films). The Program collected a variety of material on national and international film festivals that screen films about art; these are represented in the records primarily by brochures and catalogs. The "subject files" represent material used for research. These records primarily describe artists, films, organizations, art historical time periods and movements. Lastly, the Program collected posters for films (both art and non-art related); these are included in the records.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These records are organized in two series:
Series I. Program for Art on Film and Production Laboratory records, 1971-1999;
Series II. Records collected by the Program for Art on Film, 1951-1998.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: The Program for Art on Film was founded in 1984 as a joint venture between the J. Paul Getty Trust and the Metropolitan Museum of Art as a pilot project that would eventually become independent from its founding institutions. The Program's purpose was to define issues, develop programs, and disseminate information that would support the effective production and use of moving-image media that contribute to a better understanding and appreciation of the visual arts.

From 1984, the Getty Trust, through a joint venture with the Metropolitan Museum, subsidized the development of the Art on Screen Database and the Program's other projects. The Trust's support made it possible for the Program to offer a range of services to the field for free or at minimal cost during this productive development period under the joint venture, which concluded in June of 1994. From July 1994 through June 1996, the Program was based at Columbia University.

The Program was then established as an independent, non-profit 501(c)(3) corporation. In 1996 the Program affiliated with the Pratt Institute and moved its offices to the School of Information and Library Science (SILS) building, on the Institute's main campus in Brooklyn, New York. Some of the resulting programs enabled by this new joint venture were the Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen festivals.

The Program's first Executive Director was Karl Katz (1984-1992). Wendy Stein served as Program Manager and Nadine Covert served as Special Consultant, Critical Inventory during the same period. In 1992, Covert was named Manager of the Program. Joan Shigekawa served as Coordinator, Production Laboratory, from 1986 to 1990. When the Program moved to Columbia University in 1994, Covert was named Director, and served in this position until 1998, when the program was discontinued.

During its lifetime, the Program's activities included a constellation of complementary services: compiling and maintaining the Art on Screen Database (also known as the Critical Inventory); publishing Art on Screen, the newsletter of film and video on the visual arts; developing filmographies, handbooks, and other publications; reviewing and evaluating moving-image productions on art and architecture; presenting workshops and seminars for educators and museum professionals; and distributing a series of short films and videos involving collaborations between art scholars and filmmakers, produced as part of the Program's earlier Production Laboratory experiment.

Among the reference works produced by the Program were: the Art on Film Database, begun in 1984; Films and Videos on Photography, in collaboration with the Direction des Musées de France, Ministry of Culture and Communication, Paris, in both English and French editions; Art on Screen: A Directory of Films and Videos about the Visual Arts (G.K. Hall & Co., 1992); Art on Screen, a newsletter of the visual arts, and Close-Ups, the Art on Film Database Service supplement of reviews and recommended film titles; Architecture on Screen (G.K. Hall & Co., 1994); Art Museums and Media (1994), a report of survey results; and The Art on Screen Handbook: Practical Guidelines for Using and Producing Films, Videos and Interactive Programs about Art (1994).

The Art on Screen Database provided a unique critical inventory of more than 26,000 international film, video, and multimedia productions. The scope of the database included fine arts, architecture, photography, archaeology, decorative arts, design, costume, crafts, folk arts, and related topics such as aesthetics and creativity. The database was ranked among the top three databases by the Consortium of College and University Media Centers. It appeared in electronic form in 1995 as Art on Screen on CD-ROM (G.K. Hall/Macmillan). [Adapted from Nadine Covert, "Milestones: Activities and Accomplishments"]

did.unittitle: Program for Art on Film and Production Laboratory records,

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These records are organized into ten subseries: Series I.A. Administrative records, 1984-1994;
Series I.B. Publications and publication information, 1984-1988;
Series I.C. Art on Film/Film on Art records, 1984-1998;
Series I.D. Art on Screen database records, 1994-1998;
Series I.E. Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen symposia, 1992, 1997-1999;
Series I.F. Interviews, 1987-1992;
Series I.G. Conferences, seminars and workshops, 1974, 1979-1997;
Series I.H. Legal documents, 1985-1999;
Series I.I. Production Laboratory miscellaneous information, 1986-1996;
Series I.J. Miscellaneous, 1971-1979, 1984-1994.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of correspondence, letters, public relations material, clippings, reports, photographs, films, financial documents, legal documents, published material, minutes, surveys, transcripts, and audiocassettes created, published and collected by the Program for Art on Film and its Production Laboratory, 1971-1999. The records describe the development, production, promotion and distribution of Program for Art on Film projects (handbooks, newsletters, databases, and films).

The records describe the day-to-day administrative management of the Program for Art on Film through strategic planning reports, advisory and managing committee meeting minutes, and information on the Program's various joint ventures (with the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Trust, Columbia University, and the Pratt Institute). The records also describe specific Program for Art on Film projects and publications, such as handbooks and newsletters, databases, reports and resource guides, and various other programs and projects. Among the most visible of the Program's projects were the 14 films created by its Production Laboratory for its Art on Film/Film on Art series, many of which received awards. The Program's work on symposia, conferences, and educational outreach activities is documented in the records describing Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen (that also resulted in publications of the same name), Art on Film, and screenings of its films that took place around the world. The activities of the Production Laboratory are also documented in the records, and can be found throughout all of the subseries.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These records are listed by subject, and in the order found within the original accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of reports, minutes, financial documents, and planning documents created by the Program for Art on Film, 1984-1994. Included are strategic planning documents, minutes of advisory and managing committee meetings, reports on the status of various Program for Art on Film projects, fiscal reports, information on cataloging and subscription services, and information on members of the Advisory Committee.

arrangement.p: These records are listed in alphabetical order by publication or type of record, and then generally in the order found within the original accession. The "Publications files" are listed in the order found within the original accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of publications and related documents, reports, correspondence, forms, contracts, and book design work created and published by the Program for Art on Film, 1987-1998. The records describe specific Program for Art on Film projects, including the handbook Art Museums and Media; the Art on Screen Database (known as the Critical Inventory), and its manifestations in both print and electronic form; information on Architecture on Screen, one of the later projects initiated by the program; Art on Film newsletters, databases, reports and resource guides; and information on various Program for Art on Film programs and projects.
[Many of the Program for Art on Film publications exist in multiple copies and can be weeded.]
For additional information on Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen conferences, see Series I.D. Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen symposia.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: These records are organized in three subseries:
Series I.C.1. Production records, 1984-1994;
Series I.C.2. Film and video, 1988-1992 and undated;
Series I.C.3. Promotional materials, 1986-1998.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of photographs, correspondence, letters, contracts and legal documents, invoices, press materials, film treatments, photographs, awards for films, films, an audiocassette, and clippings, produced for and by the Program for Art on Film and its Production Laboratory, 1984-1998. The records describe the production, evaluation and promotion of the 14 films produced by the Program for Art on Film in a series entitled Art on Film/Film on Art. Among the artists, art historians and filmmakers who collaborated on some of these films are David Hockney, Sir Ernst Gombrich, and Philip Haas, and the records include correspondence and other documents relating to these individuals. The 14 films, which are included in the records, are: Architecture of Transcendence: Beauvais Cathedral; Painted Earth: The Art of the Mimbres Indians; The Fayum Portraits: Funerary Painting of Roman Egypt; 1867: The Execution of Maximilian; Leonardo's Deluge; MA: Space/Time in the Garden of Ryoan-ji; St. Genevieve, Pantheon of Domes; Gombrich Themes: Part 1, Illuminations in Art and Nature; Gombrich Themes: Part 2, Reflection in Art and Nature; A Mosque in Time, A Window to Heaven; Giorgione's Tempest; A Day on the Grand Canal with the Emperor of China; Trevi; De Artificiali Perspectiva or Anamorphosis; and St. Neophytos and Icons of Wishful Thinking. Information on the evaluation process for the films is also included in the records, as are awards in the form of plaques, certificates and statuettes presented to the Program for Art on Film for some of these productions. The promotional materials include press kits, testimonials and fan mail for all Program for Art on Film publications and productions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of photographs, correspondence, contracts and legal documents, invoices, press materials, film treatments, photographs and awards for films produced for and by the Program for Art on Film and its Production Laboratory, 1984-1994. The records describe the production and evaluation of the 14 films produced by the Program for Art on Film.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of photographs, clippings, letters, and promotional materials for Program for Art on Film productions, 1986-1998. The promotional materials include press kits, testimonials and fan mail for all Program for Art on Film publications and productions. Multiple copies of almost all the photographs can be found in the records.

did.unittitle: [Press Coverage: "Fan Mail" for Art on Screen: A Directory of Films and Videos on the Visual Arts (2 copies); Press Releases, etc. (3 copies); Production Lab Photos; miscellaneous press releases],
Art on Screen database and records,

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These records are listed in the order found within the accession.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records comprise correspondence, memoranda, notes, database definitions, web page printouts, database printouts, csv and xls copies of the data, and a clipping, dated 1994-1998, created by the Program for Art on Film in the course of developing their website and, in particular, the Art on Screen database and its public interface.

Most of the films documented in the Art on Screen database were produced between 1970 and 1998, with selective coverage of productions from 1915 to 1969. Each of the roughly 26,000 citations includes a synopsis, credits, country, language, production date, format, and other filmographic data. The last addition to the database was made in 1998. The database includes productions from more than 70 countries. Subjects covered include fine arts (painting, sculpture, drawing), architecture, archaeology, photography, decorative arts, design, costume, crafts, folk arts, and related topics such as aesthetics and creativity. Media formats covered include film, video, videodisc, multimedia, and CD-ROM productions. The database does not provide information about how to locate copies of the productions or where to view them.

The Art on Screen Database was hosted on Getty.edu from 2006 until the retirement of the database software in 2018. Since the database structure was extremely flat, it was decided to preserve the data as .csv and .xls files. Interested researchers may access the preserved data files through the link in the inventory below.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These records are listed in the order found within the original accession, and by project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records contain correspondence, newsletters, forms, financial documents, published materials, clippings, photographs, programs and brochures describing two projects of the Program for Art on Film, Art on Screen (1992, 1995) and Architecture on Screen (1997-1999). Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen were two symposia organized by the Program in the later years of its existence, and which also resulted in two publications, Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen. The records are primarily concerned with the symposia.
For information on Art on Screen and Architecture on Screen publications, see Series IB. Publications and publication information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of audiocassettes and transcripts of interviews conducted by Program for Art on Film personnel, 1987-1992. Interviewees included art historians, artists and filmmakers. The majority of the transcripts exist in both unedited and edited versions. Also included are transcripts of focus group interviews.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records include surveys, press releases, clippings, correspondence, letters, reports, photographs, and printed materials, 1974, 1979-1997, regarding conferences, workshops, and educational outreach activities organized, hosted, or undertaken by the Program for Art on Film and the Production Laboratory. One of the earliest conferences, "Art on Film," was held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the records document the planning activities for the conference. Education and outreach activities, such as participation in university courses, are documented in the records, as are symposia and screenings held at or with the Louvre and other museums, New York Women in Film, College Art Association and other professional organizations. Also included in the records are documents describing the planning of a seminar organized by the Production Laboratory in 1989 with filmmakers Adams and Goldbard.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of correspondence, transcripts, contracts, legal documents, release forms, and reports created for and used by the Program for Art on Film and its Production Laboratory, 1985-1999. The records document the legal activities behind the production of the various Program for Art on Film film projects (including Art on Film/Film on Art), including arrangements for screenings and distribution, and work with consultants; and provide information on the joint venture arrangement between the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Trust, the collaboration with Pratt Institute, sales of Program for Art on Film publications, and publishing information.
See also Series I.C. Art on Film/Film on Art and Series I.H. Production Laboratory miscellaneous information.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records contain financial documents, transcripts, public relations materials, legal documents, correspondence, and inventories relating to the Program for Art on Film Production Laboratory, 1986-1996. The records provide additional information, beyond the administrative, legal and financial, on the day-to-day operations of the Production Lab, such as the results of evaluations and focus groups, and information on film distribution.
Records of the Production Laboratory are scattered throughout the subseries. See also Series IG. Legal records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of press materials, letters, worksheets, surveys, reports and brochures produced and collected by and for the Program for Art on Film, 1971-1979, 1984-1994. These records support the activities documented in the preceding series, such as the reports on film and video and the articles used for research and development; many are not original materials, i.e., records produced by the Program for Art on Film. Others are blank copies of surveys and forms that provide no contextual information, or correspondence that contains no contextual information. Included are miscellaneous materials not created by the Program for Art on Film but used for administrative purposes.

did.unittitle: Records collected by the Program for Art on Film,

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: These records are organized into eight subseries:
Series II.A. Information on American film production and distribution companies and organizations, 1971-1998 and undated (bulk 1984-1994);
Series II.B. Information on international film production and distribution companies and organizations, 1972-1997 and undated (bulk 1984-1994);
Series II.C. Information on films, 1974-1996 and undated (bulk 1984-1994);
Series II.D. Information on film-related conferences, 1982-1997 and undated;
Series II.E. Subject files, 1965-1998 (bulk 1980-1990);
Series II.F. "People files", 1960-1996 and undated (bulk 1983-1996);
Series II.G. Film festival files, 1959-1998 (bulk 1984-1997);
Series II.H. Visual materials, 1985-1995 and undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of correspondence, memos, catalogs, brochures, inventories, press releases, clippings, photographs, articles, printed materials, resumes, programs, posters, books, films, magazines/journals, CD-ROMs, slides, and reports collected by the Program for Art on Film, 1951-1998. The bulk of these records were used to compile the Art on Screen ("Critical Inventory") database.

The records describe American and international companies and organizations that produce and distribute films on art; individual films (both feature and documentary) that take as subject artists or art; conferences where films on art were screened; and miscellaneous informational materials. Much of this material is promotional in nature (catalogs, brochures, and press releases).

The "Subject Files" (labeled as such by Program for Art on Film personnel) describe artists, films, organizations, projects, art historical time periods and movements, and such diverse topics as art education, attitudes towards films, international television markets, and management.

The "People Files" (labeled as such by Program for Art on Film personnel) describe artists (both contemporary and deceased, working in a variety of media), filmmakers, art historians, and other individuals with interest in film and/or the arts. Some of the individuals represented in the records served as evaluators for the Program's publications (including its films).

The records contain information in the form of catalogs, brochures, programs, and other printed matter documenting film festivals. These festivals, both national and international, were concerned specifically with films about art.

The visual materials comprise posters, slides, and image-oriented interactive visual arts software. The posters included in the records are generally advertisements for films; also included are photographic images of two projects by the artist Christo.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Records consist of catalogs, brochures, inventories, press releases, clippings, photographs, printed materials, correspondence, and reports, collected by the Program for Art on Film, 1971-1997 and undated, that describe American companies and organizations that produce and distribute films on art. Much of the material is promotional in nature (catalogs, brochures, and press releases). The bulk of the records are printed materials; any correspondence found within the records contextualizes these records, and is often in response to a direct query by Program for Art on Film personnel. Some of the information was used to compile the Art on Screen ("Critical Inventory") database.
